guide.title: Gentoo Developer Relations
guide.subtitle: Main Page
guide.abstract: The Gentoo Developer Relations Project is an effort to recruit, train, and maintain developers for the various Gentoo projects.

body.p: Gentoo Developer Relations is a project in Gentoo which aims to be a point of contact for prospective developers, as well as a point of contact for current developers. For prospective developers, we use the mailing lists, the forums and the Gentoo bug tracker to watch for, and invite, prospective developers.

The stated goal for Gentoo Developer Relations is to act as a meeting point for Gentoo developers and advanced users both. As such, Gentoo Developer Relations is concerned with both intra-developer relations as well as forming relations with advanced users and prospective developers.

The current active subprojects in Gentoo Developer Relations are:
Project: Description:
Intra-Developer Relations Here, we maintain a constantly updated roster of developers, and their areas of development. This will be not only the devlist, but also the herds document, which will list the various herd projects in the portage tree, along with the herd manager (point of contact). Additionally, we maintain a record of developers' GPG public keys to provide a single area for developer lookup.
Recruitment and Training Currently, we have a process on the Gentoo bug tracker which tracks a new developer's progress from initial contact through training and final sign up. As part of a new developer's training, they must fulfill several requirements, culminating in a quiz/questionnaire. Every new developer is assigned to a mentor on the Gentoo development team.
User Relations The goal of this subproject is to interface with the user community, to seek out motivated and skilled individuals for prospective hiring. Essentially, the concerns of the community with respect to developer relations will be listened to, and where possible, addressed. Potential developers should be able to easily learn about current projects, project goals, openings in areas where their skills may be used etc. Also there are bound to be many advanced users who may not wish to become developers, yet do have the expertise to help enrich Gentoo. We will investigate ways in which these individuals might help the development community (via document translation, bug resolution etc.) An established method of listening to user concerns regarding developments issues is important. The forums, IRC and mailing lists do a great job, but development-specific questions/suggestions/concerns should ideally be made available to the development community. Gentoo Developer Relations will aim to provide timely feedback to these suggestions, or forward their suggestions to the relevant parties.

The current planned subprojects in Gentoo Developer Relations are:
Project: Description:
Developer Conflict Resolution Grant Goodyear recently proposed a GLEP (Gentoo Linux Enhancement Proposal) calling for an Ombudsman to aid in developer conflict resolution. We would like to implement this plan in the near future. Also pro-active policies that are aimed at preventing technical/interpersonal conflicts will be developed; set channels of communication will also be developed in which developers can voice concerns (anything from technical disagreements to developer burnout) confidentially before these concerns degenerate into personal conflicts.
Recruitment Policy One of the biggest questions in the user community is how to become a Gentoo Developer. We will attempt to outline our requirements for a prospective developer as well as provide an interface for prospective developers to contact the recruitment and training team. The requirements outline will include both etiquette and development guidelines for developers. One idea would be to create a comprehensive Developers' Handbook to cover everything from development policy through etiquette expectations to conflict resolution. Currently, interested parties can contact recruiters
